hedline.hl1: Bomb Threat Forces Plane Back to J.F.K.

abstract.p: Pakistan International Airlines jet carrying Gen Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, and 120 other people returns to Kennedy International Airport because of bomb threat; pilot, on runway when threat is received, decides to take off because plane had already been searched by three teams of bomb-sniffing dogs, but has second thoughts and returns to airport (S)

block.p: An airborne jet carrying Pakistan's military ruler and 120 other people returned to Kennedy International Airport last night because of a bomb threat, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

The plane, Pakistan International Airlines Flight 722, had been searched by three teams of bomb-sniffing dogs before takeoff because the Pakistani leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, was on board, said Alan Hicks, a Port Authority spokesman.

The plane, Pakistan International Airlines Flight 722, had been searched by three teams of bomb-sniffing dogs before takeoff because the Pakistani leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, was on board, said Alan Hicks, a Port Authority spokesman.

When a 911 operator relayed word at 9 p.m. of a bomb threat, the pilot decided the Boeing 747, in line to take off, had been searched thoroughly already and took off anyway, Mr. Hicks said. But over the Boston area, the pilot had second thoughts and returned to Kennedy, Mr. Hicks said. At 1 a.m. today the passengers' luggage was still being searched.
